name: Tutorial

text.value: App version: {{application[0].version}} | Bonita version: {{session.version}}
Credit card dispute resolution: A Bonita Case Management example

Welcome to this tutorial!
You will get here an overview of how Bonita can be used to answer Case Management business needs.
Learn how it works, how to use it, and eventually how to create your own Case Management application!
Enjoy the reading!
I- Purpose of the example

The purpose of this Credit card dispute resolution application is to provide a complete Case Management example created with Bonita.
Case Management offers users a choice of tasks to perform according to their states (Required, Discretionary, Optional), as well as the possibility to create their own tasks when needed.
This example is meant to illustrate the power of the Bonita platform to implement and execute Case Management-based applications.
Using this example, you will be able to understand the main concepts and implement them in your own Case Management-based Bonita application.
II- The case management event handler

Bonita Case Management capabilities rely on an Event Handler embedded in Bonita Engine.
The event handler is triggered every time a human task is completed, and has the following effect:
All the human tasks transient variables whose name starts with `$` are re-evaluated.
Those transient variables contain the state logic. This means that you must define such a transiant variable on each human task whose state must be re-evaluated.
The value of a variable should reflect the state of the associated human task (Required, Discretionary, Optional, Not Available, Completed), depending on the execution state of the process (a given task has been completed, a given business data has been valuated, ...).
When the event handler is triggered, the values of those variables are re-evaluated, and so the state of each human task.
The state of each task is displayed in the page provided (the next Disputes tab). Only available tasks can be executed. This logic of task display is computed in a REST API extension also provided in this example.
The Case Management event handler is already activated

Activate the Case Management event handler

By default, the Case Management event handler is not activated. To activate it, the following argument has to be passed when launching the Tomcat:

-Dcom.bonitasoft.engine.plugin.acm.REGISTER_ACM_HANDLER=true

In Bonita Studio, you can enable the event handler by going to Preferences → Server settings → Check Enable ACM event handler.

Activate the Case Management event handler

By default, the Case Management event handler is not activated. To activate it, the following argument has to be passed when launching the Tomcat:

-Dcom.bonitasoft.engine.plugin.acm.REGISTER_ACM_HANDLER=true

In Bonita Studio, you can pass this argument to the engine Tomcat by going to Preferences → Server settings → Tomcat JVM additional arguments. The parameter is present by default, you just have to set its value to true.
III- Set up the example

In order to be able to use this example, check that the following artifacts have been deployed:
  1. Business Data Model bom.xml
  2. Organization ACME.organization
  3. Processes Credit Card Dispute and Data initialization
  4. REST API extension creditCardDisputeResolutionRestAPI
  5. Application descriptor credit-card-dispute-resolution
  6. Finally, refresh this web page

In order to be able to use this example, there is a couple of artifacts to deploy.
All the artifacts can be deployed from the Bonita Studio using the Deploy action: Right click on the project → Deploy... or click on the Deploy... icon in the toolbar
  1. Select all the artifacts
  2. Choose the Local environment
  3. Use daniela.angelo as default username (or any user mapped to the process initiator actor for a case)
  4. Click on Deploy
  5. Open the Credit Card Dispute Resolution application
IV- Data initialization

The Credit Card Dispute process requires the pre-existence of some data:
  • An account contains all the transactions of a given customer
  • A dispute is started following the call of an existing customer who wants to dispute a transaction on its account
The database must be populated with some customers, accounts, and transactions before a new dispute can be started. We thought that existing disputes would also be nice to exist in the dispute list to offer a sense of reality.
So we have implemented a process that creates those data: DataInitialization.

label.value: Create customers, accounts, transactions and disputes

text.value:
Something bad happened
{{dataInitError.message}}
Data created
Customers
V- Open the application and create a dispute

We simulate here a situation where a customer calls the Customer Service to dispute a transaction, and a the Customer Service employee starts a new dispute case with the ID of the calling customer.
The database now contains the required data to start a case of the Credit Card Dispute process.

You can now {{mainAppsLink}} (second tab of this application example).
This page displays the list of the opened disputes.

Only members of the actor Customer Service, mapped to the group acme/sales, can start a new credit card dispute.

Daniela Angelo answers this criterion. If you are not already logged with Daniela Angelo, log out and log in with:
User: daniela.angelo
Password: bpm

Create a new dispute by clicking on the New dispute button (top right hand corner).
A customer ID will be asked to start the dispute. You can pick one from the customer list above.
The User Interface
The main User Interface of the dispute resolution is organized in several zones:
An the top, information about the customer and the current dispute. This information is updated when actions are performed.

In the mid-left zone, the task list. It contains all available actions for the current user, and their states.
Each action corresponds to a human task in the Credit Card Dispute process.
The state of a task can be Required Discretionary Optional N/A (not available) or Completed
If you look at the process, you can see on each task a transient data named $activityState, that computes the state of its task via the event handler.
As explained above, depending on its state, the task can be performed or not, by clicking on its name.
Above this list,the buttons zone. Among them, the special Task button. It is used to create an unplanned action that needs to be performed for this particular case (send a mail to someone, call a customer, ...).
Once created, the new action is available in the task list, and can be performed at any time.

In the mid-right zone, the History of the case. It contains a summary of all the tasks performed during the dispute resolution.
At the bottom of the page, the Comments zone contains all the comments added during the dispute resolution (report of a call with the customer for example)
Further down, the Documents zone contains all the documents added during the dispute resolution (Customer bills for example)
VI- Gather dispute details

The first required action of the Credit Cart Dispute process is the Gather Dispute Details task: the customer is on the phone with Daniela Angelo, and explains the issue to her.
As Daniela Angelo still, click on the task Gather Dispute Details.

You have here the possibility to enter details about the dispute (according to what the customer on the phone is telling you), and then to Reject or Follow-up on the dispute, depending on whether you consider it valid or not.
The Merchant Identification Number (MIN) corresponds to the identifier of the merchant who performed the transaction the customer is disputing. If the customer doesn't know it, it can be retrieved later, during the Dispute Investigation.
For the sake of this tutorial, enter an amount of 600 USD, a random date in the past, and follow-up on the dispute.
VII- Investigate transaction

The next required action to perform is the action Investigate Transaction. The customer gave details about the dispute during the first call, a Dispute Agent has now to investigate.

Joseph Hovell is a Dispute Agent (the actor mapped to the group acme/production). Log out and log in with:
User: joseph.hovell
Password: bpm

During the investigation, the Dispute Agent will, for exemple, find the Merchant Identification Number associated with the disputed transaction.
  • Perform the action Investigate Transaction, add the following comment: MIN found using customer transaction date
  • Perform the action Update Dispute and add a Merchant identification Number (Exemple: 10-0002363)
The database has been populated with transactions, you can find the MIN of a transaction by looking into the account details, if you want to simulate a real investigation
VIII- Chargeback

After the investigation, the Dispute Agent decides to Charge back the customer.

Perform the action Update Dispute, and set the status to PROCESSING CHARGEBACK

The action Chargeback should still be unavailable, because the amount to charge back is higher than the Review amount threshold (default value: 500) A Dispute Supervisor has to perform a review to authorize the chargeback.

Zachary Williamson is a Dispute Supervisor (the actor mapped with the group acme/finance). Log out and log in with:
User: zachary.williamson
Password: bpm

Perform the action Review, with the following comment: Review done, chargeback authorized.
The dispute supervisor has also the possibility to change the review amount threshold, by performing the action Update parameters. If you set the threshold to a value higher than the amount to charge back, then the review is not required anymore.

Log in with Joseph Hovell, and perform the action Chargeback.
The customer has been charged back, and an email notification has been sent to its inbox. If the email connector has not been properly configured, the failure is just ignored. You may configure a valid smtp server in the process administration panel.
You can now resolve the dispute by clicking on the Resolve button.
IX - Known limitations

This example is using an event handler, as described in II here above. In case you have a big amount of cases and activities, you should monitor overall system performances and potentially do some tuning.
Activities have dynamic names including an icon, which makes it simpler to create buttons in the application and forms. As a consequence, activity names would not display properly in the Bonita Portal tasklist. Furthermore, case visualization in the Monitoring page of the Bonita Portal would not display acitivity names properly neither.
X - Further steps

Starting from this example, you can go further with the implementation, using all other Bonita capabilities.
In case you want to translate the application to other languages, you can use UI Designer multi-language support. You can add localization assets for your forms and pages as explained in Bonita documentation.

mainAppsLink.value: return "open the main application";
